Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrated Computational Optical Framework for Quantitative Space-Variant Imaging in Live-Cell Fluorescence Microscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Integrated computational optical framework for quantitative space-variant imaging in live-cell fluorescence microscopy

This research is developing new computational methods to integrate with a novel optical non-scanning imaging system design to enable fast live-cell fluorescence microscopy imaging with high, isotropic 3D resolution. The PI has pioneered computational methods for DIC microscopy. This work addresses a key challenge in live-cell microscopy of accounting for aberrations due to ?thick? biological specimens. Refractive index (RI) mismatch and heterogeneity within thick samples produce image distortions that worsen with imaging depth in conventional microscopes. Commercially available deconvolution methods do not account for these distortions. To address this issue, the PI is utilizing computational Differential Interference Contrast (DIC) microscopy to develop new corrective methodologies and integrate computational development into a new system design using a computational optical sensing and imaging (COSI) system approach. This is a novel and innovative application of adaptive optics. Specific research is developing mathematical models that can accurately predict data acquired with a wide-field imaging system; using model-based data processing algorithms to estimate accurate fluorescence concentration in 3D images and developing a software package for the user community. Performance and utility of the new methods is being tested on cytoskeletal proteins.

The broader impact activities are diverse and innovative. The PI is developing coursework that integrates imaging science and optical systems to complement research in computational imaging for microscopy and COSI system design. The PI is establishing cross-disciplinary participation in her courses, particularly among engineering, biological sciences, and pre-medicine majors. A interdisciplinary certificate program with concentration in Microscopy will result.

The PI?s commitment to multidisciplinary education and outreach is preparing the next generation of biological researchers and engineers for work at the intersection of biology, computational science and engineering disciplines where significant advances are expected to further revolutionize science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to address a key challenge in live-cell microscopy. Refractive index  mismatch and heterogeneity within thick samples produce image distortions that worsen with imaging depth in conventional microscopes. Commercially available computational methods for digital image processing do not account for these distortions and result in artifacts that hinder biological study. The research performed during this project has led to the development of new computational-optical techniques that account for imaging aberrations due to “optically thick” biological specimens, thereby improving the ability of the light microscope to focus deeper into biological samples.

A computational optical framework that enables further development of imaging techniques for the study of optically thick samples (OTS) i.e., samples that are physically thick and/or have significant refractive index variability, such as lung tissue, has been developed and evaluated with simulations, and  validated with experimental data. Improved imaging models that characterize microscope response when imaging OTS has been developed and evaluated with simulations, and validated with experimental data. Improved 3D image restoration of OTS based on more accurate imaging model and data from a more robust imaging system (i.e., less sensitive to aberration due to OTS) has been developed and evaluated with simulations and experimental data. System modifications that render the system more robust to imaging aberrations due to OTS have been implemented and calibrated. The modified system has been used to acquire images from test samples and biological samples that are optically thick.

Several undergraduate and graduate students (including students from underrepresented groups) received training and research experience in a comprehensive principled approach for quantitative biological imaging system development, with direct application to important imaging problems where significant advances are expected to further revolutionize science. All the students that participated in this project have successfully earned degrees at the BS, MS and PhD level, accordingly.

The direct impact of the results of this project is within the bounds of science, engineering and academia.  However, beyond these bounds, our results are likely to make an eventual impact on the manner in which diseases, that society suffers from, are diagnosed and treated. Through new observations enabled by development of advanced microscope techniques, changes in understanding of microbiology directly influences understanding of disease and disease response to medication. This is especially true at the present time when cell studies are rapidly moving from 2D to 3D platforms and tissue engineering is an expanding field; previous understanding is being revised in light of new observations enabled by the 3D cell culture and tissue structure. Our results are part of a greater effort to create tools for non-invasive high-resolution observation of volumetric cell cultures. In turn, such studies will eventually bear changes in the field of medicine and in society’s methods for maintaining health.

In the particular case of our biological collaboration of lung tissue imaging, this project has resulted in the development of a space-variant imaging model and image restoration algorithm which directly addresses the problem of maintaining high resolution in the extremely heterogeneous lung-tissue environment. Previously, no existing imaging model could predict the data acquired from this type of sample with sufficient accuracy for quantitative fluorescence microscopy due to large changes in refractive index along multiple directions.
